mechanismDescription: President Carlos Saúl Menem decreed an amnesty (Pardon No. 1003/89) for left-wing guerrillas awaiting trial for crimes committed during the 1970s
amnestyName: Pardon 1003/89. Pardon to people included in specific judicial proceedings
narrative: President Menem released a series of pardons in 1989 in the name of national reconciliation and this is Pardon 1003/89 or also known as Decreto 1003. It was created on October 7, 1989 and covers several leaders and low-tier members of left-wing rebel groups, who were responsible for crimes committed during the 1970s. These members were held in detention awaiting trial for these crimes or fugitives in exile. Some of the left-wing guerrilla leaders, who were pardoned, were Fernando Vaca Narvaja and Roberto Perdía. The pardon also covers those who were listed as “wanted” in some court cases, but who were also known to have disappeared after their detention in the course of the “dirty war.” However, President Menem also stated that the pardon will not covered any “subversives,” who had been charged in court. Due to international pressure, the pardon also does not cover Mario Eduardo Firmenich, who was the former leader of the Montoneros. He was sentenced to 30 years in prison for the 1974 kidnapping of Juan and Jorge Born. At the same time, President Menem mentioned granting future pardoning of Firmenich.
qualifyingProcess: The pardon will not covered any “subversives,” who had been charged in court.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were included in amnesty

mechanismDescription: The "Law On the Innocence and Amnesty of those formerly Convicted and Political Persecuted" (Law No. 7516) provided amnesty to political prisoners and exiles, excluding opponents of the communist dictatorship, for crimes against the state
amnestyName: Law 'On the Innocence and Amnesty of those formerly Convicted and Politically Persecuted', No 7514
narrative: Known as the Law “On the Innocence and Amnesty of those Formerly Convicted and Political Persecuted,” this amnesty law (No. 7516) was implemented on September 30, 1991 and later amended by law No. 7660 on January 14, 1993 and law No. 7719 on June 8, 1993. The Albanian government wanted to increase its public support by creating this amnesty law, which is for political prisoners. The amnesty specifically grants amnesty to those who were sentenced for running for power against the state, but not those who opposed the communist dictatorship. In other words, it grants amnesty to those who were in a leading opposing party or governmental role. Those not granted an amnesty are allowed to seek trial and prove their innocence to the court. The amnesty also covers Albanians who fled the country because of their political beliefs, affiliation, or activities during the war (Article 2). The amnesty law specifically spells out that those who gave out orders that led to “arrests, imprisonments, deportation, and displacement of families, due to the class struggle, and who have been active in using means to violence against the prisoners in the investigation office, prisons, camps, etc.” will not be granted amnesty (Mallinder Amnesty Law Database). Those who have been convicted or murder because of terrorist acts will also not be granted amnesty.
qualifyingProcess: Excludes those who being in leading party and state posts have committed crimes against the state, because they have been sentenced in the course of running for power and not because they opposed the dictatorship.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes are not relevant to this amnesty

mechanismDescription: The government offered an amnesty to Islamic insurgents
narrative: The purpose of this amnesty was to "offer a chance for whoever belongs to the misguided group [al Qaeda] and is still at large following involvement in terrorism operations to repent, plead guilty and voluntarily surrender" (NYTIMES). It seems as if the amnesty was targeted mainly toward new recruits of al Qaeda, rather than those who already had engaged in attacks. It was also not expected to cover leaders of al Qaeda responsible for killings. Crown Prince Abdullah said in a televised address, on behalf of King Fahd, that militants who turn themselves in will be treated fairly under God's law and spared the death penalty. But those who didn't will invoke the wrath of a government that derives its power from god. Mohsen al-Awaji, an Islamist lawyer who sought to mediate between the government and militants, said 'God's law" meant those who gave themselves up would not face state prosecution but would be subject to civil charges. Prince Faisal said that "the state will drop its claim on these criminals if they give themselves in, but the private claims of the families of those who were killed or who were assaulted or who were wounded will remain for them to decide" (Mallinder).
qualifyingProcess: - time limit of one month - Must surrender voluntarily to security forces.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were included in amnesty

mechanismDescription: Decree No. 30-90-E provided full amnesty to all political prisoners and leftist guerrillas for political and associated common crimes and to members of the military for human rights violations committed during the 1980s
narrative: Ley Concediendo Amnistía, Decreto número 30-90 was implemented on December 5, 1990. Initially, the general amnesty law was for political prisoners, who were detained, convicted, or in jail because of political or related crimes. Those in prisoner were mostly leftist guerillas. The amnesty also covered exiles. There are not any mentioning of excluded crimes. On December 14, 1998, the Court of Appeals decided to apply this amnesty law to cover the military’s human rights violations. The Court of Appeals determined in a unanimous verdict that the military’s crimes were committed because of the unique situation the nation was undergoing. Despite the fact that the amnesty was extended to all citizens, in its preamble, the National Congress mentioned the cases of farmers, who according to criminal law were considered terrorists, although their only intention was to acquire land and was not an attempt against state security. Article 3 stated that foreigners could benefit but they must leave the territory within a reasonable period of time (GLIN 1990). On 14 December 1998, the Court of Appeals decided to extend this amnesty to cover human rights violations by the military. The unanimous verdict by the Court ruled that the amnesty also covered the military since their crimes were committed in the 'special situation' the nation was undergoing at the time (Mallinder).
hrCrimes: human rights crimes are not relevant to this amnesty

mechanismDescription: The government passed a general amnesty for political prisoners detained during the anti-government protests of July 1987 and for citizens accused of participating in political crimes related to the crisis that began on June 8, 1987
narrative: This amnesty law was approved by the Legislative Assembly and ratified by President Eric Arturo Devalle. It went to effect on July 14, 1987. There are speculations that the amnesty was proposed on behalf of General Antonio Noreiga. This legislation grants amnesty to political prisoners, who were arrested in a violent anti-government protest weeks prior to the introduction of the bill, or since June 8, 1987. This includes about 700 Panamanians, who committed criminal acts and 90 people who were allegedly involved in political crimes. Amongst those granted amnesty is Colonel Roberto Diaz Herrara, a retired former Chief of Staff of the Panamanian Defense Forces. Exiled leaders of the anti-government movement were also granted immunity, including Aurelio Antonio Barria—Chairman of the Chamber of Commerce. However, political prisoners, who committed crimes against state institutions are excluded from the amnesty law.

mechanismDescription: The 1981 Amnesty Decrees provided amnesty to anti-communist rebels for fighting the pro-Soviet governments in Kabul since 1978
narrative: On 18 June 1981, the National Committee of the National Fatherland Front issued a statement on the amnesty decree proclaimed by the Presidium of the Afghan Revolutionary Council. In this statement, it stated: "in accordance with this decree, every citizen of the DRA, both military and the civilian, who due to the deceit of the enemies of freedom, national independence, national sovereignty, territorial integrity and the enemies of religion and honour of our beloved country Afghanistan, have left the country and live under conditions characterized by suffering, terror, and misery, or those who either by the disgraced American imperialism or the Chinese renegade leadership and their stooges, the militant government of Pakistan are trained and equipped, in case they lay down their arms and surrender themselves shall be granted total amnesty.
qualifyingProcess: In a speech on 31 July 1981, President Karmal stated 'decree was issued to give the deceived individuals the opportunity and a specified period of time in which to rectify their mistakes. Of course this opportunity is only available for a short period'. He did not, however, specify when the deadline would occur. It appears that the government continued to invoke this amnesty decree and defections continued under its terms for the duration of the Soviet- backed communist government and it formed part of a National Reconciliation Policy proclaimed in 1986. Article 1 of the June 1981 Amnesty Decree stated 'all individuals who lay down their arms and surrender themselves voluntarily to the state organs will be granted amnesty'. These organs included the security forces. To benefit from amnesty the guerrillas were required to surrender to state organs and disarm.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were included in amnesty
sourceInformation: Political Prisoners Freed. (1981, April 27). Reading Eagle , p. 19.

mechanismDescription: Presidential Proclamation No. 4313, 39 provided amnesty to military officers and soldiers for draft evasion and military desertion during the Vietnam War from August 7, 1964, and March 29, 1973
amnestyName: Presidential Proclamation No. 4313, 39 Fed.Reg. 33293 (16 Sep 1974), reprinted in 50 U.S.C.A. App. Section 462 (1978)
qualifyingProcess: - Executes an agreement acknowledging his allegiance to the US and pledging to fulfil a period of alternate service under the auspices of the Director of Selective Service, and satisfactorily completes such service. Amnesty was based on a programme of earned re-entry through two years of alternate public service. Each member of the armed forces who elects to seek relief through this programme will receive an undesirable discharge. Thereafter, upon satisfactory completion of a period of alternate service prescribed by the Military Department or Department of Transportation, such individual will be entitled to receive, in lieu of his undesirable discharge, a clemency discharge in recognition of his fulfilment of the requirements of the programme. Such clemency discharge shall not bestow entitlement to benefits administered by the Veterans Administration. - Must present themselves to a US Attorney. - Deadline is 31 Mar 1975.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes are not relevant to this amnesty

mechanismDescription: President Violeta Chamorro decreed an amnesty for detainees, accused, wanted, and convicted Nicaraguans for political offences, politically motivated crimes, and human rights violations
narrative: The Nicaraguan Congress approved Ley de Amnistía, Discréto No. 47-91 on December 28, 1991. The amnesty covers anyone detained, on trial, sentenced, awaiting trial, or not captured but wanted, and those serving their sentence for political or related crimes, or common crimes that were politically motivated. Those who have served their sentence will be pardoned. It covers the time period from May 10, 1990 to the implementation of this amnesty legislation. The amnesty is broad and unconditional, requiring the immediate release of those imprisoned or held. The amnesty law excuses serious human rights violations. Since Nicaragua adopted the Convention on the Imprescriptibility of War Crimes and Crimes against Humanity, the amnesty does not cover war crimes.

mechanismDescription: The provisional government offered amnesty to political prisoners for their involvement in the January 7, 1991 coup attempt and to state agents for human rights violations
narrative: On December 24, 1991, Haiti’s Provisional government passed an amnesty law that granted pardon to political prisoners who were convicted of politically related charges before and during Aristide time as President, from December 16, 1990 to September 27, 1991. At least 20 men were involved in an attempted coup d’etat on January 7, 1991. The amnesty law also decreased sentence of Luc Desyr (a former Protestant minister who led the secret police, Tonton Macoute, during the Duvalier family’s 29-year rule) from 30 years to 5 years. Desyr was responsible for many killings and reputedly direct many torture sessions.

The Federal Appeals Court shall examine the complaint and assume jurisdiction over the case if appropriate

mechanismDescription: Law No. 26479 provided a general amnesty to military, police, and civilian government personnel for all crimes committed in the course of combating terrorism from May 1980 to June 15, 1995
amnestyName: Ley No. 26479 and related Ley No. 26492
narrative: Ley Nº 26479 Conceden amnistía general a personal militar, political y civil para diversos casos of June 14, 1995 was later modified by Ley Nº 26492 Precisan interpretación y alcances de amnistía otogada por la Ley Nº 26479 (28 Jun 1995), published in Normas Legales. The Democratic Constituent Congress passed the law and then President Fujimori promulgated it. It went into effect on June 16, 1995. It was a blanket amnesty that pardoned military and police members regardless of status, “who face a complaint, investigation, criminal charge, trial, or conviction for common or military crimes, whether under the jurisdiction of the civilian or military courts, in relation to all events derived from, or originating in, or as a consequence of, the fight against terrorism, and which may have been committed individually or by two or more persons between May 1980” and the day the amnesty went into effect (Article 1). In other words, the amnesty covers crimes of torture, forced disappearances, and extrajudicial killings along with fraud and arms purchases. Though the amnesty seems broad, it excluded insurgents. Opinion polls estimated that 80% of the Peruvian population did not support the amnesty legislation.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were included in amnesty

mechanismDescription: The Pinochet government decreed an amnesty (Decree-Law No. 2191) for all government and military forces for illegal acts committed during the state of emergency from September 11, 1973, to March 10, 1978
amnestyName: Ley de Amnistia Chilena. Decreto Ley 2191
narrative: The Chilean Amnesty Act of 1978 is also known as the Pinochet Amnesty Act. It was drafted in 1978 by Pinochet’s regime and promulgated on April 18, 1978 as Executive Decree No. 2,191. It was created to minimize the regime’s exposure to judicial accountability. Articles 1 and 2 provide blanket amnesty for all offences committed under the 1973’s State of Siege. However, the Decree also gives plenty of exceptions to make sure that broader amnesty would not be granted if not completely necessary. One of the significant exceptions is Article 1, which denies amnesty to anyone currently on trial or serving a sentence, which in practice translates to anyone the junta has decided to prosecute. The amnesty also designated crimes that would not be cover such as, narco-trafficking, robbery, bribery, rape, incest, or embezzlements (Article 3).
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were included in amnesty

mechanismDescription: The Amnesty Law of 2014 provided an amnesty for citizens who committed crimes against state security or military crimes in the context of the Mozambican National Resistance (RENAMO) insurgency from March 2012 to August 14, 2014
narrative: The amnesty is part of a peace deal between Renamo and Guebuza's ruling Frelimo party, old foes in a 1975-1992 civil war, and means Dhlakama will not face prosecution or arrest for the attacks carried out by his followers over the last year. The law grants amnesty for all crimes against state security, all military crimes, and all crimes against persons and property committed in connection with security and military offences. (From March 2012 until the day of the law's passing & applies to similar cases which occurred in Dondo District at the Administrative Post of Savane in 2002, in Cheringoma District in 2004, and in Maringue District in 2011) The amnesty is worded broadly enough to cover not only such security offences as high treason and armed rebellion but also crimes of murder, arson, theft and illegal possession of firearms. The peace agreement between the two parties was signed the 25 of August.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were included in amnesty

mechanismDescription: Decree No. 7338 provided amnesty to convicted political prisoners for being fugitives or for agitation and propaganda
narrative: Known as Decree No. 7338, this amnesty law was proclaimed on November 13, 1989 and implemented on November 20, 1989. The Ministry of Internal Affairs, the Supreme Court, the General Bureau of Investigation, and the Office of the Prosecutor General are the state bodies responsible for carrying out this amnesty law. Out of all the people convicted for crimes against the state, the amnesty only excused those who had been sentenced as being fugitives, and for agitation and propaganda. Article 47(G) of the Penal Code spells out the rest of the pardon, which also includes those under the age of or will reach the age of 18, and who will reach the age of 60 by the time the amnesty goes into effect. The amnesty also covers all women who have served a sentence of up to 15 years, given a lesser or conditional sentence. Those who have been given amnesty are to return back to their place of residence and to work where the government “needs them in order to become worthy citizens” (Article 2). The state and the Albanian society are to assist those who have been pardoned.
qualifyingProcess: The amnesty did not apply to those serving sentences for crimes against the state. All persons benefiting from this amnesty and who are released are to go to their places of residence and are to work where the country needs them in order to become worthy citizens of the People?s Socialist Republic of Albania. Society and the state bodies are to give them the necessary assistance
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were excluded from amnesty

mechanismDescription: Legislative Decree No. 22 provided a general amnesty for Syrian nationals held on charges of terrorism committed before June 9, 2014
narrative: Few detainees benefitted as confessions were coerced through torture, incurring sentences more severe than the ones amnestied by the decree.
qualifyingProcess: Those who deserted from the army will be extended a full pardon if they hand themselves in within three months of the decree. The decree also grants amnesty for foreigners who entered Syria with the purpose of joining a terrorist group or committing a terrorist act if they turn themselves in to the authorities within a month of issuing this decree. The amnesty also gives a chance to those carrying unlicensed weapons, granting them two-month deadline for handing their weapons over.

mechanismDescription: Amnesty Law No. 163 provided a general amnesty to Nicaraguan insurgents for political and associated common crimes, such as armed rebellion against the government, prior to August 28, 1993
narrative: Ley de Amnistía, Ley Nº 163, or Amnesty Law No. 163 went into effect on September 23, 1993. The National Assembly approved the legislation on August 17, 1993 with support from 45/92 Sandinista deputies. Before voting, the UNO withdrew their support from the process because of their discontent with the amnesty and Junta Directiva. Article 1 of the amnesty legislation states that the law covers anyone who took up arms because of political objectives or for socio-economic reasons until August 28, 1993. This date was extended to cover the rearmed groups that tookover the city of Estelí and other groups, who took hostages in the Quilalí municipal and in the UNO headquarters in Managua. It also covers “Nicaraguan members of irregular groups belonging to the self-styled ‘Frente Norte 3-80’ and ‘Commando Dignity and Sovereignty’ for the political and related common crimes committed with the reason of kidnapping, which occurred in Aug 1993 in the town of Zúngano, Municipality of Quilalí, and at the headquarters of the Union Nacional Opositora (UNO) in Managua” (Mallinder Amnesty Law Database). Those who want amnesty must voluntarily give up their weapons and military equipment no later than September 15, 1993 to security zones established by the government.
qualifyingProcess: - time limit by 28 Aug 1993. - Must demobilise voluntarily surrender their weapons and military equipment not later than 15 Sep 1993 by joining the security zones previously established by the ministry of governance by 28 Aug 1993 (art 3) Covers those who already demobilised between 18 May 1993 and the entry into force of the law (art 3). Covering Nicaraguan members of irregular groups belonging to the self- styled ?Frente Norte 3-80? and ?Commando Dignity and Sovereignty? for the political and related common crimes committed with the reason of kidnapping, which occurred in Aug 1993 in the town of Zúngano, Municipality of Quilalí, and at the headquarters of the Union Nacional Opositora (UNO) in Managua, without having to comply with requirements that to qualify for amnesty must voluntarily appear before the Representative of the Ministry of the Interior established for such purposes, and then get the Charter Demobilization referred to in the preceding article of this Act.(art 5)
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were excluded from amnesty
sourceInformation: Amnesty International report 1994: Nicaragua. United States Department of State, U.S. Department of State Country Report on Human Rights Practices 1993 - Nicaragua, 30 January 1994, available at: http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/docid/3ae6aa4e26.html [accessed 9 August 2011]

mechanismDescription: The "Law of National Pacification" (Law No. 22,924) provided amnesty to all members of the armed forces for crimes against terrorist or subversive organizations between May 25, 1973, and June 17, 1982
amnestyName: Law 22,924 of National Pacification (Ley de Pacificacion Nacional)
narrative: The Law of National Pacification, also known as Law No. 22.924 was passed on September 23, 1983 by the military regime. The military regime spent more than a year drafting up the law and its decree was delayed for several months due to disputes concerning its temporal and criminal jurisdictions. The legislation grants amnesty to military and government officials, who have committed political and related crimes. The regime used both television and radio outlets to advertise and endorse the amnesty. Opposition groups, trade unions, the Roman Catholic Church, and human rights NGOs opposed the amnesty. Although it pardoned military officials, many also opposed the amnesty because it gave the impression that they are responsible for or have actually committed crimes. On December 27, 1983, Congress repealed the amnesty legislation of the previous regime. Congress declared the amnesty law null and void. “This was possible because under a new conception of the validity of laws enacted by authoritarian governments, the law was treated as a de facto imposed norm which, as such, did not carry the presumption of validity enjoyed by norms of democratic origin. Therefore, it would be valid only if its content were just.” After just days of taking office, on December 10, 1983, President Alfonsín issued a decree that arrested high-ranking military officials for trial of the crimes they committed during the previous regime. The amnesty law covered all criminal activities related to or resulting from terrorist or subversive acts, but excludes members of illicit terrorist organizations. It only covers the period between June 17, 1982 (resignation of President Galtieri) and May 25, 1973 (return of the civilian government). June 1982 was a cut-off date to ensure that the then present military junta could not be held judicially accountable. This law also covers participants, instigators, accomplices, military and police members (Article 1). It even protests members of the paramilitary death squads, who kidnapped and killed hundreds of people under the approval of the military. The amnesty also covers international crimes, such as, crimes against humanity, stating: “'The penal actions arising from the crimes committed with terrorist or subversive motivation or objective between 25 May 1973 and 17 Jun 1982 shall be declared annulled. The benefits granted by this Law extend, in the same way, to all criminal activities resulting from or motivated by the development of actions directed at the avoidance, prevention or termination of the terrorist or subversive activities mentioned, whatever may have been their nature or the legal tenet violated” (Article 1). The amnesty excluded about 250 people, who had been charged with terrorist crimes by military and civilian courts. The amnesty also excluded economic crimes.
qualifyingProcess: Excluded from the benefits provided in the preceding Article are members of illicit terrorist or subversive organisations who, on the date until which the benefits of the Law remain effective, do not reside legally and openly in the territory of the Argentine Nation or in places subject to its jurisdiction, or who have demonstrated by their conduct an intention to continue their connection with these organisations.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were included in amnesty
sourceInformation: Garro, Alejandro and Dahl, Enrique, 1987. Legal Accountability for Human Rights Violations in Argentina: One Step Forward and Two Steps Backward. Human Rights Law Journal 8: 283-344 Mallinder Amnesty Law Database Mallinder, 2009;The Ongoing Quest For Truth And Justice: Enacting And Annulling Argentina Amnesty Laws. mechanismDescription: Congress passed an amnesty for approximately 250 rioters arrested during the October 2, 1968 demonstrations
narrative: On October 2, 1968 in the Plaza de las Tres Culturas in Mexico, military and police officers killed about 300 students. This event is considered to be a part of the Mexican Dirty War, in which the regime used repression tactics to quell political opposition. Out of about 3,000 people at the riot, more than 1,300 people were arrested. Although there were massive human rights violations, the amnesty only covers crimes related to the riots and rioters. Though there were about 1,300 people arrested, the amnesty law also only covers an estimated 250 individuals.
qualifyingProcess: approximately 250 individuals who had been arrested during the student riots of October 1968.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes are not relevant to this amnesty

mechanismDescription: Amnesty Law 8202 provided amnesty to civilian and military personnel for crimes committed during the January 10 to March 11, 1997 riots
narrative: Albania’s 1997 Amnesty Law 8202 is a modification of Amnesty Law No. 8198 and has some added provisions. It went to effect on March 27, 1997—the same month and year of No. 8198. This amnesty extends coverage to more crimes committed during the 1997 riots than the previous Law No. 8198. Article 1 lists a wide range of crimes not covered by this amnesty, including premeditated murder, sexual violence, kidnapping, prostitution, genocide, crimes against humanity, and torture with serious consequences. Article 2 states “[a]ll persons being criminally prosecuted or convicted for committing the crimes cited in Article 1 are to have their sentences reduced by a third if they voluntarily return to prison by 12.4.1997, while those sentenced to life imprisonment or death are to have their sentences reduced to 20 years’ imprisonment.” The Ministries of Justice, Interior, Defense, and Prosecutor General are all responsible for implementing this amnesty.
qualifyingProcess: All persons being criminally prosecuted or convicted for committing the crimes cited in Article 1 are to have their sentences reduced by a third if they voluntarily return to prison by 12.4.1997, while those sentenced to life imprisonment or death are to have their sentences reduced to 20 years’ imprisonment.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were included in amnesty

mechanismDescription: The government extended a 1985 amnesty law for Contra rebels by one year
narrative: Ley de Amnistía General, Nº 36 repealed the 1987 amnesty law and was approved by the National Assembly on April 24, 1988 after the Constitutional Government of Nicaragua and the Nicaraguan Resistance agreed to the Sapoá Accords on March 23, 1988. This amnesty law pardons army personnel for crimes committed before July 19, 1979. Article 3 guaranteed that the Sandinista government would grant amnesty to the former regime’s army members, who were charged for rebellious crimes and to those who were charged with violating the law on order and security. The amnesty also applies to all Contra leaders and members, even those outside the country. The amnesty went through three phases of releasing political prisoners instead of releasing everyone immediately. First, 100 prisoners were released on Palm Sunday (March 27, 1988), then half of the remaining Contra prisoners were released on April 15 when the Contras moved to designated ceasefire zones, and then once the ceasefire agreement was finalized, the remaining prisoners were released. The amnesty law was extended until December 23, 1988 and again on September 3, 1989.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes are not relevant to this amnesty

mechanismDescription: Amnesty Law No. 100 decreed a general amnesty to all Nicaraguans, for political and related offences committed between 1979 and 1990, including human rights violations and repression
narrative: Not to be confused with Nicaragua 1990’s Law No. 81, this other 1990s amnesty is Law No. 100, which was a Presidential Decree approved by the National Assembly. It is also known as La Gaceta, N º 100, 23 May 1990, No. 98, p. 1064, which replaced Law No. 81 It was created on May 9, 1990. The legislation applies to “all those detained, prosecuted, sentenced, pending trial, still at large, and prisoners that have served out their sentence, as well as those who have been granted a simple pardon…” (Article 1). It also permits former Somoza guards and others to return back to their country. The amnesty also concerns those who were involved in political and related acts from before 1979 (the year of the dictator Somoza's downfall) to the present day.

mechanismDescription: Article 445 in Chapter 14 of the 2008 Constitution provided amnesty to state agents for "any act done in the execution of their respective duties"
amnestyName: Article 445 in Chapter 14 of the 2008 Constitution
narrative: Effective amnesty through which no legal action can be taken against members of the State Law and Order Restoration Council and the State Peace and Development Council. The amnesty provision is contain in the new 2008 Constitution, Article 445 in Chapter 14 entitled 'Transitory Provisions' of the Constitutions states: 'No proceeding shall be instituted against the said Councils or any member thereof or any member of the Government, in respect of any act done in the execution of their respective duties.' According to ICTJ's analysis (2009: 33), the clause does not specify which acts would be covered by the amnesty. It only holds that it applies to “any act done in the execution of their respective duties.” This language could be interpreted widely to encompass administrative, civil, and criminal activities. Alternatively, it may be interpreted more restrictively, for example holding that any act done in violation of national or international law must, by definition, have been outside the scope of “their respective duties.” Such a restrictive interpretation of this immunity clause would permit criminal liability for severe human rights abuses. It is not clear whether the amnesty is intended to apply only to past actions or present and future actions. How these ambiguities are interpreted will likely depend on the new judiciary. It appears to be up to the national courts to decide that these serious crimes could not, by definition, have been part of an individual’s official duties because such acts violated Burma’s national laws, treaty obligations, or international law. Such a position appears unlikely, however, in the current context in which the Burmese courts function as an extension of military rule (ICTJ 2009: 37). According to the Burma Lawyers' Council, this Article, also known as the Immunity Clause, grants amnesty for any regime official who has committed any crime, as long as the crime was committed as a result of their official duties.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were included in amnesty
sourceInformation: Burma Lawyers' Council. International Center for Transitional Justice, September 2009. IPS (2008) RIGHTS-BURMA: New Constitution Gives Impunity to Military. qualifyingProcess: No conditions are explicitly listed in the amnesty law. However, media coverage indicates that there was an understanding that to benefit from the amnesty, combatants must surrender and disarm. Two disarmament sites would be opened from 19 June for those who wish to surrender: one at Aveba, 70km north of Bunia, and one at Kpandroma, 120km north of Bunia. Upon disarmament, militiamen would receive certificates to distinguish themselves from the militia who had not surrendered.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were excluded from amnesty

qualifyingProcess: Article 5 provides 'To qualify for amnesty, perpetrators , co-perpetrators or accomplices of insurrectionary acts and acts of war covered by this law are first required to personally commit, in writing, on their honour not to repeat the acts that are the subject of this amnesty.' It continues that this commitment must be honoured within six months of the date of the law's publication in the Official Journal. Article 5 provides that 'Any violation of this commitment [to renounce and refrain from insurrectionary acts and acts of war] will automatically void the amnesty granted and thus disqualify the author of the violation of the benefit of any subsequent amnesty.'

amnestyName: Ordinance No. XIX of 1975, also known as The Indemnity Ordinance
narrative: The Indemmity Ordinance 1975 (Ordinance No. XIX of 1975) was implemented on September 26, 1975. The Bangladeshi Parliament unanimously adopted this law on September 26, 1975. According to Article 2.a. of the legislation, it provided immunity “any person including a person who is or has, at any time, been subject to any law relating to any defence service, for on account of or in respect of any act, matter or thing done or step taken by such person in connection with, or in preparation or execution or any plan for, or as necessary step towards, the change of Government of the People’s Republic of Bangladesh and the proclamation of Martial Law on the morning of the 15 Aug 1975.” On August 15, 1975, there was an attempted military rebellion and this amnesty excuses those who participated.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were included in amnesty

mechanismDescription: The government under Ríos Montt passed a 30-day amnesty (Decree-Law 27-83) for guerrillas for political and associated common crimes
narrative: Decreto Ley 27-83 went into effect on March 15, 1983. The legislation grants amnesty to leftist guerrillas or accomplices, who indirectly or directly contributed to violence against the political or judicial state institutions of Guatemala. The amnesty law excuses political and related crimes that “subversive” groups have committed and to be granted an amnesty, individuals must voluntarily appear within 30 days of March 29, 1983. The amnesty law granted an additional 30 days after under Decree Law 43-83 of April 27, 1983. The amnesty excludes those who were subjected to criminal prosecution or those who have already been sentenced.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes are not relevant to this amnesty

narrative: The National Stability and Reconciliation Law was passed by parliament in 2007 by a coalition of powerful warlords and their supporters to prevent the prosecution of individuals responsible for large-scale human rights abuses in the preceding decades. The amnesty law states that all those who were engaged in armed conflict before the formation of the Interim Administration in Afghanistan in December 2001 shall ""enjoy all their legal rights and shall not be prosecuted.""(HRW 2010)

mechanismDescription: The "Law on the Status of Politically Ex-Convicted and Prosecuted People by the Communist Regime" (Law No. 7748) provided amnesty to political prisoners, the communist elite, and many state officials for political crimes committed between November 8, 1941, and March 22, 1993
amnestyName: Law on the Status of Politically Ex-Convicted and Prosecuted People by the Communist Regime, Law No. 7748
narrative: The Albanian 1993 amnesty is known officially as the Law on the Status of Politically Ex-Convicted and Prosecuted People by the Communist Regime (Law No. 7748), which went into effect on July 20, 1993. The legislation was approved by parliament and was later amended by Law No. 7771 of December 7, 1993. The amnesty law excludes a broad category of state officials, but Article 3 states that the amnesty covers “a) The high communist nomenclature approved by the Council of Ministers. b) Associates of the state security, witnesses of the political trials, the activity of who has led directly to crimes such as murder, imprisonment, internments, banishments etc. of the citizens. c) Political convicts, that in the content of the verdict, the part of crimes such as theft, robbery, murder, serious bodily injury have it equal to or larger than the political sentence, as well as rapists. d) Political convicts or internees, who in the content of their political sentence have also ordinary counts mentioned in point ‘c’ of this article and before this sentence have been sentenced another two times for theft and robbery, in spite of their sentence. e) Persons categorized according to art 3(d), when they have lost the moral right to be called as such, due to the public negation of their political beliefs or due to the negation of having relations with the people close to them, categorized according to art 3(a)(b)(c)(d) when this thing is certified in writing by the prosecuted person himself according to the above points, as a result of prosecution” (Mallinder Amnesty Law Database). The amnesty covers the period between November 8 1941 and March 22 1993.
qualifyingProcess: Individuals who suffered from any act or failure to act between 8 Nov 1941 and 22 Mar 1993 on the part of any armed formation or individual of the National Liberation Army, the state security service, the police, the army, or a local government organ on the basis of an order or decree of the party, military, state or judicial organs of the Albanian communists, when this act or failure to act led to loss of life, freedom, of civil rights or classification as kulak or declassed person, as well as any other debarment of the individual from political, economic and social life because of his political or religious convictions or attitudes
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were included in amnesty

mechanismDescription: President Aristide decreed an amnesty to all civilians and state agents for political crimes and involvement in the September 30, 1991 coup
narrative: The 1993 Governors Island Agreement (A/47/975-S/26063) was passed on July 3, 1993 and reiterated in the New York Pact of July 16, 1993. The Governors Island Agreement was a peace agreement mediated by the UN and support from the OAS and US, which led to the 1993 Presidential decree of October 3, 1993 that also subsequently led to the 1994 Amnesty Act. This amnesty act is also known as Loi relative à l'amnestie, which was drafted by President Aristide and passed on October 6, 1994. Fifty out of fifty-two deputies from the Chamber of Deputies approved the legislation. In the Senate, it was approved by 9 Senators and one Senator voted against it with 1 Senator absent. This legislation gave President Aristide the authority via Article 147 of the 1987 Constitution to pardon those who was involved in the September 30, 1991 coup d’etat. It also gave full amnesty to all military and civilian persons who committed political offenses and international crimes, such as crimes against humanity under the authoritarian regime. It covers only the temporal period under the regime of September 29, 1991 to July 3, 1993.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were included in amnesty
sourceInformation: TJDB; Mallinder

mechanismDescription: Law No. 819 provided amnesty to civilians and military personnel for crimes committed during the January 10 to March 11, 1997 riots, as well as convicted prisoners who were freed during the unrest
amnestyName: Law 8198. Amnesty for people, civilian and military personnel implicated in riots after the bankruptcy of Fraudulent Pyramid Schemes
narrative: The 1997 Law on Amnesty for civilians and military personnel who were involved in the riots after the collapse of fraudulent pyramid schemes, or Law No. 8198 was implemented on March 11, 1997. This amnesty law was supported by 10 big Albanian political parties and was thus approved by parliament. There was some civil unrest regarding this amnesty law. Those who are granted amnesty include military members, who during the time of the riots between January 10, 1997-March 11, 1997, committed penal crimes. It does not cover crimes that were committed during the riot, but were premeditated and had no connection to the riot except that it was committed during that time. This amnesty law also covers convicted prisoners, who escaped prison when armed groups broke in and destroyed these jails. In addition, President Berisha also pardoned other prisoners if they had less than 2 more years to serve. He also specifically excused then Socialist Party Chairman and Prime Minister Fatos Nano on March 14, 1997. The amnesty does not cover international crimes, such as crimes against humanity.
qualifyingProcess: Surrender weapons by 20 Mar 1997. Convicts return to prison by ???, later extended to 15 Jan 1998. People who have arms, munitions and other military equipment, and who did not commit penal acts after 11 Mar 1997, are excluded from justice provided they surrender their weapons and ammunition by 20 Mar 1997. Offers a reduction of one-third of the conviction time for those individuals who agreed to return to prison before ???, following their temporary liberty resulting from the civil unrest.

mechanismDescription: The Amnesty Law No. 1 provided amnesty to all counter-revolutionaries for participating in armed opposition
narrative: The National Assembly in Nicaragua passed Ley de Amnistía, Nº 1 and the amnesty law went into effect on January 29, 1985. The President in his inaugural speech introduced the amnesty. The legislation covers members of opposition group, who had taken arms against the state in an anti-government movement. Specifically, Article 1 states “All Nicaraguans who are actually involved in counter-revolutionary activities, including those of an armed nature.” This amnesty can be applied to leaders of these groups, who were previously excluded in past amnesties. Exiles in Honduras or Costa Rica were to give up arms to the governmental authorities in those countries, the International Red Cross, or Nicaraguan consulates. Members of these groups had to surrender their weapons to the Nicaraguan authority. The Nicaraguan Episcopal Conference deems this inclusion as a positive achievement. The amnesty was applicable until July 19, 1985, but it was extended until September 3, 1985, again until August 20, 1986, and lastly once again until July 27, 1987.
qualifyingProcess: - Valid until 19 Jul 1985. It was extended on 3 Sep 1985 and again on 20 Aug 1986 and on 27 Jul 1987. - Must surrender and hand over their weapons to the competent authorities (arts 1-2). Nicaraguans in Honduras or Costa Rica can take their weapons to the authorities of the governments in those countries, the international Red Cross, or Nicaraguan consulates (art 3).

mechanismDescription: The "1996 National Reconciliation Law" (Decree No. 145-96) provided amnesty to military personnel and guerrilla groups for human rights violations and political crimes relating to the conflict
amnestyName: 1996 National Reconciliation Law (Ley de Reconciliacion Nacional), Decree 145-96, hereinafter NRL
narrative: The 1996 Madrid Peace Accords between the Guatemalan government and the Unidad Revolucionaria Nacional Guatemalteca (URNG) rebel created a negotiated amnesty law for both sides in the armed conflict. The 1996 Peace Accords was implemented through the 1996 National Reconciliation Law, which passed in a 65-8 vote with 7 abstaining. The amnesty was broad and provided pardons for government officials who committed even common crimes to try to suppress the rebel group. The text of the amnesty has been interpreted to provide more protection for government officials than it does to rebels. State officials are immune from “penal responsibility for common crimes committed with the aim of impeding, frustrating, suppressing, or punishing the commission of political acts.” Rebels were granted amnesty to political crimes such as, sedition, illicit association, crimes against national security, and weapons-related crimes. The amnesty leaves extrajudicial killings by security forces and deliberate and arbitrary killings by the rebels open to the interpretation of the courts. It excludes international crimes for which Guatemala is a party to and serious human rights violation, such as genocide, torture, and forced disappearance (Article 8). It also excludes any crime that demonstrates personal motive (Article 3). Article 5 grants the appellate courts the power to “grant amnesty to state actors for common crimes perpetrated to prevent or repress crimes committed by the guerrillas.”

mechanismDescription: President Endara extended an amnesty to over 578 former government officials for committing political crimes during the dictatorship of General Noriega
narrative: There were a series of amnesty laws in Panama in 1994. The first one was on July 7, 1994. On this day, President Endara granted pardons to 578 former state officials, who were accused of political crimes under the former dictator, Noreiga. These political crimes were widespread, including corruption to the murder of an American teacher. The pardon gave legal amnesty to many who played small roles under Noreiga, but excluded those who were Noreiga’s closest military associates. These associates remained in prison. On June 26, 1994, the Former Chief of State of the Armed Forces, Colonel Roberto Diaz Herrara, who was convicted and sentenced to five years of imprisonment, was also granted amnesty. This amnesty is supposed to exclude torture.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were excluded from amnesty

This legislation grants amnesty to Panamanian citizens, who participated, were accused and prosecuted for crimes specified in Chapter 1, title 3, Article 306 of Title 9 Chapter 2, and Article 372 of Title 12, Chapter 1 of the Second Book of the Criminal Code. To be granted an amnesty, these crimes had to be committed between June 1, 1987 and December 24, 1987.

mechanismDescription: Law No. 01.NS.94 provided amnesty to members and defectors of the Khmer Rouge, with the exception of leaders, for offences committed during their time in power
amnestyName: Law on the Outlawing of the Democratic Kampuchea Group, No.01.NS.94.
narrative: Loi Relative À La Mise Hors-La-Loi De La Clique Du Kampuchéa Démocratique, Loi Nº 064 was adopted by the National Assembly of the Kingdom of Cambodia on July 7, 1994 during the 2nd Session of its first legislature. The amnesty law was promulgated by Decree No. 01/NS/1994 on July 15, 1994. This amnesty is supposed to pardon the Khmer Rouge members, who committed crimes while in power in the 1970s. The amnesty law excused former Khmer Rouge members, who defected to the government side between July 7, 1994 and January 7, 1995. However, the amnesty does not cover “leaders” of the Khmer Rouge and the term “leader” is not defined in the legislation. It gives King Norodom Sihanouk the authority to grant full or partial amnesty based on his discretion. Amnesty can only be granted within the first 6 months of its implementation. On October 5, 2004 during the negotiations of the Khmer Rouge Tribunal, the Cambodian Parliament approved another law preventing the government from granting any amnesty or pardon to Khmer Rouge suspects.
qualifyingProcess: Time limit of within six months of it taking effect. Guerrillas had to defect to government side.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were included in amnesty

mechanismDescription: President Gizikis decreed a blanket amnesty for state agents and opponents for all political crimes committed prior to June 26, 1974
narrative: Presidential Decree 519, Government Gazette, A211 was a President decree implemented on July 26, 1974. Although the amnesty did not garner much publicity, it was at the heart of an intense debate about Karamanlis’ government—the new government’s right to prosecute those associated with the past regime. The amnesty pardons all criminal actions related to the “State of Siege” until the date of the amnesty law’s publication. Those who are imprisoned for these crimes are to be released from prison. The legislation gave the Athens Court of Appeal with the power to investigate, charge, and adjudicate cases against the leaders of the rebellion. The amnesty does not clearly state whether it also excuses acts taken by those most responsible and secondary leaders of the dictatorship for the 1976 coup d’état. Furthermore, its exclusion clause states: “'Those chiefly responsible for political crimes and related preparations, which were directed against the constitutional order resulting from the Constitution of 1 January 1952 and directed at the establishment of the regime of 21 April 1967 which, in the meaning of the Presidential Decree (PD 519/1974), are certainly not included in the amnesty proclaimed by this decree.”

mechanismDescription: Decree No. 11 provided amnesty to citizens for political offences and associated common crimes committed between September 2, 1969, and May 28, 1981
narrative: Decreto No. 11, La Gaceta, No. 23.415 was passed by the Asamblea Nacional Constituyente on May 28, 1981. This amnesty covers political and related common crimes committed between September 2, 1969 and the enactment of the amnesty law. The legislation helped a large number of Hondurans, who were detained for several reasons. The amnesty not only pardoned, but also reduced sentences. It does not cover repeat offenders, people on trial for crimes of parricide (the killing of parent, murder, infanticide, and robbery with murder.

qualifyingProcess: - Application for the grant of amnesty shall be filed under oath with the NCSI or P/CPOC-ACs within six (6) months from the effectivity of this Proclamation - Applicants with firearms should turnover their firearms within thirty (30) days from their filing of application for amnesty without incurring liability for illegal possession thereof. Firstly, the applicant was required to submit a written application on the prescribed amnesty application form and this application had to be made under oath and attested by a commissioner of oaths. Secondly, where necessary the applicant may be called to appear before a public hearing of the Amnesty Committee.

mechanismDescription: The "1993 Law on General Amnesty for the Consolidation of Peace" (Decree No. 486) provided amnesty to state agents and dissidents for political crimes or common crimes committed by more than 19 people, occurring before January 1, 1992
amnestyName: General Amnesty Law for the Consolidation of the Peace
narrative: The 1993 Law on General Amnesty for the Consolidation of Peace (Ley de Amnistía General para la Consolidación de la Paz), or Decree No. 486 was passed on March 20, 1993. The National Assembly voted the 47-9 with 13 abstentions for the bill. The El Salvadorean Legislative Assembly was controlled by President Cristiani’s party, which helped rapidly progressed the enactment of the amnesty law. The amnesty was opposed by 22 lawmakers of the National Assembly, who walked out in protest. Nevertheless, the amnesty legislation was passed five days after the Truth Commission released its report. The amnesty covers political crimes or politically-related crimes as well as common crimes committed by at least 20 people before January 1, 1992. The amnesty covers both civil and criminal liability. Article 1 of the amnesty states that the amnesty “is granted in favour of all those who in one way or another participated in political crimes, crimes with political ramifications, or common crimes committed by no less than 20 people, before 1 Jan 1992, regardless of whether proceedings against them for the perpetration of these crimes have commenced or not, or whether they have received a sentence as a consequence. This amnesty will cover all those who participated as direct or indirect perpetrators or accomplices in the above-mentioned crimes. The pardon will extend to those mentioned in art 6 of the Law of National Reconciliation…" (Mallinder Amnesty Law Database).
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were included in amnesty

mechanismDescription: The "Law of National Pacification" (Law No. 15.737) provided amnesty to political prisoners for all politically motivated crimes committed after January 1, 1962
amnestyName: Ley Nº 15.737 - Se aprueba la Ley de amnistía (22 Mar 1985) - also called Law of National Pacification
narrative: Known as Se Aprueba la Ley de amnistía (22 March 1985 and Ley N° 15.737, or in English—the Law of National Pacification, this amnesty law was implemented through a June 27, 1985 Decree 256/985 on March 22, 1985. This legislation pardons political prisoners. Before the promulgation of this amnesty law, 99 prisoners were released on February 27, 1985, but 226 remained in jail. To advance the releasing of the remaining political prisoners, President Sanguinetti sent a ‘national pacification’ bill to Congress on March 1, 1985—the day of his inauguration. On March 5, 1985, the House of Representatives passed a blanket amnesty bill in a vote of 55-39, but the President opposed this type of amnesty, favoring a broad amnesty that excluded those of murder. After much debate, the House of Representatives concluded a final vote that passed the bill with 86 out of 91 votes. The bill was then sent to the Senate, which passed the bill by 24-3. The amnesty bill represents a compromise between Sanguinetti’s party and the opposition (Blanco Party) in which all political prisoners would be released, but the “special provisions for violenjt offenders were viewed as not condoning their actions.” This amnesty legislation authorized the releasing of all political prisoners within a three-month period. It covers common military crimes committed after January 1, 1962. It excluded those charged for violent crimes that needed to be reviewed in civilian courts and security forces members who were accused of human rights violations. It also excluded international crimes such as, murders and crimes committed by police or military officers, “who may have been perpetrators, co-perpetrators or accomplices in inhuman, cruel or degrading treatment, or in the detention of persons who subsequently disappeared, and about whom they may have concealed any of this behavior” (Article 5). This bill also designated the State to create a National Repatriation Commission to receive returning exiles.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were excluded from amnesty
sourceInformation: 1. Amnesty Law Database (Mallinder) 2. Text of the Law 15,737, http://www.juridicas.unam.mx/publica/librev/rev/iidh/cont/1/leg/leg1.pdf

mechanismDescription: The 1987 Amnesty Law (Decree No. 805) provided full amnesty to state and non-state actors for political and common crimes related to armed conflict prior to October 22, 1987
amnestyName: Decree 805. Ley de amnistia para el logro de la reconciliacion nacional
narrative: El Salvador’s Arias Peace Plan, or Ley de Amnistía para el Logro de la Reconciliación Nacional, Decreto Nº 805, Diario Oficial Nº 199 was implemented on October 27, 1987. The Legislative Assembly approved this amnesty law with 33 votes from the Christian Democrats (government party) and 27 abstaining votes from the opposition party, who refused to vote because they did not agree with the bill’s provisions. The legislation also garnered 21 cotes from the conservative party—the National Conciliation Party. Thus, the final vote was 45-0 in a 60-seat assembly. Human rights groups and insurgents did not support this bill. The legislation received pressure from the military to cover all political crimes so that the crimes of military members and death squads were covered. Article 1 of the legislation details the beneficiaries of the full amnesty, which includes national or foreigners, who were directly or indirectly involved in political or related common crimes committed on or before October 22, 1987, in which the number of participants is no less than 20. As a result, about 750 political prisoners, who were awaiting trial, were freed. The amnesty excludes crimes, such as, kidnapping, extortion, drug-related crimes, and economic crimes. The amnesty had a 15-day limit. For guerillas to be granted amnesty, they had to appear before civil or military authorities and state that they will relinquish any desire to commit violence.
qualifyingProcess: Guerrillas must appear before civil or military authorities and state their desire to renounce violence and accept amnesty within 15 days
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were included in amnesty

mechanismDescription: The "Esuipulas II Agreement" provided amnesty to Nicaraguan nationals for offences related to violating laws concerning the maintenance of order and security
narrative: Esuipulas II Agreement (Arias Plan) of August 7, 1987 was implemented through the November 19, 1987 Ley de Amnistía para Detenidos por Violación de la Ley de Mantenimiento del Orden y Seguridad Pública, No 33. The Sandinista government did not want to support the amnesty provisions as detailed in the Arias Peace Plan. There was a strong push from the human rights sector and inter-governmental organizations to get the amnesty through. The National Assembly passed the amnesty law on November 19, 1987. The amnesty law pardons Nicaraguans, who had been convicted and sentenced for violating laws regarding public order and security from July 20, 1979. The amnesty does not cover former members of the National Guard under the Somoza regime, who committed crimes against Nicaraguans because they were not sentenced under the Law on the maintenance of public order and security. Instead, they were trialed for violating a penal code that is not covered by the amnesty. Eventually, the amnesty was given to about 1,600 prisoners accused of Contra activity. The Sandinista government timed the releasing of these prisoners with funding decisions that US Congress made. On November 29, 1987, the Nicaraguan government gave amnesties to 985 prisoners. 779 of the prisoners were arrested and sentenced for violating the law on public order and security while the Special Courts convicted 206 of these prisoners.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes are not relevant to this amnesty

qualifyingProcess: - Objects used or intended to be used for the commitment of an offence for which amnesty has been granted pursuant to article 3[1], or objects produced by such objects, shall forfeit to the State whenever, by their own nature or by the circumstances of the case, they pose a serious risk of being used in the commitment of new offences. - Under Article 3, for crimes such as theft, extortion, robbery, burglary, embezzlement, fraud, the offenders were required to 'prior reparation to the victim'. Article 10 stipulated 'Amnesty and pardon provided for in the present law shall be granted on condition that the beneficiary is not to commit another malicious offence in the succeeding three years from the date of entry into force of the present law, in which case the penalty applied to the supervenient offence shall be added by the penalty or part of the penalty of the pardoned offence.

mechanismDescription: Decree No. 87-91 provided amnesty to members of the military for suspected human rights abuses, and to civilians for political and associated common crimes committed during the 1980s
narrative: Decreto Nº 87-91, La Gaceta, No 26.498 was passed on July 10, 1991 by the National Congress (Congreso Nacional). The amnesty pardons all military members, who were being investigated for human rights abuses, and political prisoners as well as jailed peasants for land disputes. Those who had been charged were to be freed and current and accused defendants were dismissed. The amnesty also covers political and related crimes as well as common crimes committed before June 24, 1991, such as killings, torture, and unlawful arrests. It does not cover international human rights crimes.

mechanismDescription: King Norodom Sihanouk decreed an amnesty (Royal Decree No. NS?RKT/0996/72) to former Deputy Prime Minister of the Khmer Rouge, Ieng Sary for gross human rights violations committed while in office
narrative: Known officially as Royal Decree (Reach Kret), NS/RKT/0996/72, this amnesty law went into effect on September 14, 1996. This amnesty was specifically created to pardon Ieng Sary. On August 19, 1979, Ieng Sary was convicted of genocide and other criems, and sentenced to death along with Pol Pot by the People’s Revolutionary Court of Phnom Penh in absentia. Thus, almost 20 years later, King Norodom Sihanouk gave out a royal decree giving amnesty to Ieng Sary, former Deputy Prime Minister of the Khmer Rouge government. The two former Co-Prime Ministers at the time—Prince Norodom Ranaridh (the King’s son), and Hun Sen (still Prime Minister of Cambodia) requested the amnesty for Ieng Sary. In exchange for recognizing the new coalition government with only Hun Sen leading as the sole Prime Minister, Ieng Sary was granted amnesty. He was excused of human rights violations and his convictions, and permitted to maintain control over a NW province called Pailin—a strong Khmer Rouge populated area. On October 5, 2004 during the negotiations of the Khmer Rouge Tribunal, the Cambodian Parliament approved another law preventing the government from granting any amnesty or pardon to Khmer Rouge suspects. “Under this legislation, the tribunal also would have the authority to retroactively decide on the ‘scope’ of pardons granted before the tribunal law was adopted, in a measure apparently aimed at the pardon of Ieng Sary, the former Khmer Rouge foreign minister” (Mallinder Amnesty Law Database).
qualifyingProcess: The amnesty was granted in return for Sarys defection from the Khmer Rouge, referred to the decree as the Democratic Kampuchea Group.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were included in amnesty

mechanismDescription: Decree No. 743 provided amnesty to civilians and military personnel, including members of the Sandinista Liberation Front, for political and associated common crimes
narrative: On December 3, 1978, Nicaragua’s National Congress passed Decreto No. 743 Concédase Amplia e Incondicional Amnistía a Civiles y Militares, or Law No. 743, which was a full and unconditional amnesty law. This amnesty law covered civilians and military people convicted or charged of political or related common crimes. The also amnesty covered: fighting an insurgency (for military), those inducted since the previous amnesty law that pardon political crimes from March3, 1976 to December 11, 1978. The legislation was introduced because of demands from opposition political parties. It went into effect on December 13, 1978. The amnesty covered 4,000 people, including political prisoners and exiles, and members of the Sandinista Liberation Front. In pardoning exiles, the Consuls of Nicaragua abroad were to immediately give passports to those who wished to return back. In order to receive amnesty, members of the Sandinista Liberation Front must surrender their weapons. The amnesty also applies to common and civil liability crimes.
qualifyingProcess: - Members of the Sandinista Liberation Front must lay down their weapons.

mechanismDescription: The military junta under General Mejia Victores passed a 90-day amnesty (Decree-Law 89-83) for guerrillas for political crimes and associated common crimes
narrative: Decree Law 89-83 was promulgated on August 11, 1983 and pardons left-wing guerillas, who were involved in political or related common crimes during the past two decades. This legislation can only be applied to those who were at the time subject to ordinary courts of law provided that they had not yet been convicted or sentenced. In other words, it only applies to those detained and/or awaiting trial. Thus, this amnesty excludes those who have been convicted or sentenced. Participants or accomplices of such political crimes were given 90 days to apply for an amnesty. The temporal period was later extended to November 15, 1983 for an additional 60 days and then again on January 18, 1984 for another 60 days. Those who asked to be given an amnesty must surrender their weapons and take an oath swearing that they will never participate in subversive acts again. They must also confess to the political crime(s) they have committed.
qualifyingProcess: - Must surrender and hand over weapons. - Must take an oath pledging that they would no longer participate in subversive activities. - Must confess any crimes committed for political motives during the last 20 years. - Time limit of 90 days. It was extended on 15 Nov 1983 for a further 60 days and again on 18 Jan 1984 (also for 60 days).
hrCrimes: human rights crimes are not relevant to this amnesty
sourceInformation: “Chapter IX: The Coup d’état of August 8, 1983.” Inter-American Commission on Human Rights. <http://www.cidh.org/countryrep/Guatemala83eng/chap.9.htm>. “Timeline.” International Justice Monitor. <http://www.ijmonitor.org/efrain-rios-montt-andmauricio-rodriguez-sanchez-timeline/>.

In order to benefit from the amnesty, offenders who have not yet been identified or against whom proceedings have not yet been taken, are encouraged under art 2 to sign an undertaking to discontinue their activities. - Underground members or Solidarity activists abroad must detail their past actions.

mechanismDescription: Decree-Law No. 71-87 provided amnesty to individuals responsible for political crimes and associated common crimes committed against the state
narrative: Congress implemented the Arias Plan through Decreto Ley Nº 71-87 on October 24, 1987. The amnesty covered guerillas for political crimes or related common crimes they perpetrated against the state. The legislation obligated the judge to order the release of all convicted of or detained for such crimes. It also dismissed any fines related to the crimes committed. The amnesty covered international crimes, such as, crimes against humanity. Those requesting an amnesty had to surrender their weapons and were given 180 days to do so, which terminated on March 2, 1988. In order to do so, they must go to either the court, departmental government offices, the major’s office, or nearest military base within the given time period and express their right to seek the protection of this amnesty bill. Then they will be given a document signifying the actions taken and be guaranteed protection and freedom.
qualifyingProcess: time limit of 180 days (ended 2 Mar 1988) and those amnestied must surrender weapons.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were included in amnesty

mechanismDescription: The military junta under General Mejia Victores passed an amnesty (Decree-Law 18-85) for security forces for human rights violations
narrative: Decree Law 18-85 was an amnesty granted under General Meija Victores’ regime to military and police members who committed human rights abuses. It is not entirely clear whom this amnesty covers; a news source claims it also covers guerrillas. The amnesty went into effect on March 11, 1985. It is an extension of a previous amnesty law—Decree 89-93, which was created in 1983.

mechanismDescription: A peace treaty provided amnesty to 14 rebel groups
narrative: There is a disagreement between the parties to the treaty on wether an amnesty was granted to the rebels and the nature of the crimes covered. Although it appears that the armed groups demand for a general amnesty by the CAR government was rejected, and thus that the amnesty only regards less serious crimes, this is contested. Hassan Bouba, the political coordinator for Union for Peace in the Central African Republic, said that a general amnesty was implicit in the accord. Moreover, there are speculations of a secret deal on amnesty having been reached between the government and rebels
hrCrimes: don't know

mechanismDescription: The "Limitations Act/Law of Expiry" (Law No. 15.848) provided a complete amnesty to members of the security forces for human rights abuses committed between 1962 and March 1, 1985
amnestyName: Ley 15.848 de Caducidad de la Pretension Punitiva del Estado (Law on the Expiry of the Punitive Claims of the State)
narrative: The Uruguayan amnesty law of 1986 is also known as Law N° 15.848 (Ley de Caducidad de la Pretensión del Estado) was approved by the Uruguayan Parliament on December 22, 1986 and approved by a national referendum in April 1989. This amnesty relates to human rights crimes committed by the military government (the Armed Forces) in power in Uruguay from August 1984 to March 1, 1985. During this time, the government pursued a systematic policy of repression and eliminated oppositions of the government through forced disappearance [pg. 8]. This amnesty covers military and police officials who received order(s) from their superiors and carried them out for political reasons or to fulfill their occupation obligations. It does not cover judicial proceedings in which the indictments have been released before this amnesty law goes into effect. Pending cases can be submitted to the Executive branch to determine if it falls within the scope of the amnesty law. This amnesty also does not cover crimes that were committed for personal economic advantage or to benefit a third party. This amnesty law is incompatible with the American Convention on Human Rights, which Uruguay is a party to. When it comes to prosecuting crimes during this period, the Uruguayan government has claimed that it is unable to because the previous democratic government approved this law. As a result, the amnesty law has impeded the investigation of domestic cases, such as the Gelman case.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were included in amnesty

mechanismDescription: The "Final Agreement for the Termination of the Conflict and the Construction of a Stable and Lasting Peace" provided amnesty to members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) guerrilla group and military for minor crimes committed during the civil war
amnestyName: Final Agreement for the Termination of the Conflict and the Construction of a Stable and Lasting Peace
narrative: The law is a key part of the historic peace agreement signed in November 2016 between the government and rebels from the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC). Rebel fighters found guilty of committing minor crimes during the civil war are granted amnesty. The same law also applies to members of the military. Rebels found guilty of committing serious crimes, such as massacres, sexual violence or kidnapping, do not fall under amnesty. Other laws tied to the peace deal include rural reform, compensation to victims, removal of land mines and a United Nations-monitored ceasefire.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were excluded from amnesty
sourceInformation: Deutsche Welle, 2016, "Colombia passes amnesty law for thousands of FARC rebels" https://global-factiva-com.myaccess.library.utoronto.ca/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=DEUEN00020161229ecct0005l&drn=drn%3aarchive.newsarticle.DEUEN00020161229ecct0005l&cat=a&ep=ASE Reuters, 2016, "Colombia Congress approves amnesty for thousands of FARC rebels" https://global-factiva-com.myaccess.library.utoronto.ca/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=LBA0000020161228eccs014a1&drn=drn%3aarchive.newsarticle.LBA0000020161228eccs014a1&cat=a&ep=ASE

mechanismDescription: The military junta decreed an amnesty for all Miskito Indians and Nicaraguan citizens for crimes committed against state security, except for guerrillas responsible for terrorist attacks
narrative: Ley No. 1352, Amnistía a Miskitos, Gaceta Nº 275, Decreto Nº 1352 de 1 de diciembre de 1983 was an amnesty law created in Nicaragua in 1983. The legislation went into effect on December 4, 1983. Daniel Ortega—the junta coordinator, read the decree at the closing of the National Congress’ session. The amnesty covered those who have been convicted or were involved in illegal acts against the public order and state from December 1, 1981. This covered not only Nicaraguans, but also Miskito Indians. In reality, the amnesty covered 10,000 insurgent fighters and thousands of exiles, who committed crimes against public security or related crimes against the state. Those who committed such crimes and fled the country are allowed to receive pardon and return back. The amnesty is offered until February 21, 1984, but it was extended until November 4, 1984. The amnesty excluded guerillas, who planned terrorist attacks.
qualifyingProcess: - The decree offered pardons until 21 Feb 1984. The amnesty was extended for successive periods up to 4 Nov 1984.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes are not relevant to this amnesty

qualifyingProcess: - The grant of immunity is dependent on the performance of a visible act of remorse serving the interests of the people affected by the original offence. - S 23.1 provides that each person who wishes to participate in the Community Reconciliation Process must submit an individual statement to the commission that lists the acts for which the reconciliation is sought. S 23.1 requires that the initiation of a Community Reconciliation Process must be accompanied by an explanation of the association of the reported act ?with the political conflicts in East Timor. Those who fail to surrender information and assume responsibility for their actions remain criminally liable.

narrative: The amnesty most notably apply applied to: Mohamed Fahmy, an Egyptian Canadian, and Baher Mohamed, an Egyptian, sentenced to three years in prison last month for allegedly fabricating news to support the banned Muslim Brotherhood. Four activists - Sanaa Seif, Yara Sallam, Omar Hazek and Peter Galal Youssef - Egypt's protest law has long been the epicentre of wide criticism by domestic and international human rights organisations which say it violates international standards for peaceful protest. Sisi's pardon comes one day ahead of his visit to New York to head Egypt's delegation at the United Nations General Assembly's 70th meeting.

mechanismDescription: King Bhumibol decreed an amnesty for protestors arrested during the Black May demonstrations, and for security personnel who used excessive force against the protestors
narrative: Royal Act granting an amnesty 'for offenders in the rallies on 17-21 May’ was an executive decree. It was supported by the Thai King and went into effect on May 24, 1992. The Thai Parliament opposed the decree because it was a public anti-government protest but the public prosecutors worked on it until he became a decree. This amnesty pardons all offenders, who participated in the public demonstration between Mary 17, 1992 and Mary 21, 1992, and the military officers, who used excessive force against the protestors. The legislation led to the immediate release of those detained. When the amnesty was created, it was interpreted to only apply to criminal proceedings, but in 1999, this interpretation expanded to cover civil suits as well as determined by the Supreme Court.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were included in amnesty

mechanismDescription: The "National Reconciliation Law" (Decree No. 147) provided amnesty to rebel groups for political crimes committed prior to January 1, 1992
amnestyName: Legislative Decree 147 of 23 January, the National Reconciliation Law
narrative: The Law of National Reconciliation, or formerly as Legislative Decree 147, Official Journal 14, Vol 314 (23 Jan 1992), this amnesty law was first introduced by a special Peace Commission and it implemented the “Chapultepec Agreement.” The legislation was unanimously approved by the National Assembly, which included 84 members of the main political parties. The restricted amnesty covers any accused of political crimes or related acts, and for those who took part in common crimes committed by at least 20 people prior to December 31, 1991. The amnesty does not cover those who have been convicted by juries, which is a specific clause created to officers, who were convicted for murder of 6 Jesuit priests. Anyone mentioned in the Truth Commission Report will not covered by the amnesty because the crimes they committed represented grave acts of violence. The amnesty law is allowed to grant pardons for both criminal and civil proceedings. “The law that takes effect on 1 Feb 1992, declares a general amnesty for all but those people who have been convicted by a civilian court - an exemption that prevents the immediate release of two army officers convicted of killing six Jesuit priests in Nov 1989. A limited amnesty was passed by the legislature in 1992 on the heels of the peace accords. Excepted from its terms were those cases within the mandate of the Truth Commission (although which cases would be addressed by the commission had not yet been determined). Includes those detained, but not tried, on suspicion of guerrilla affiliation. All leftist rebel leaders to return to the country” (Mallinder Amnesty Law Database).
qualifyingProcess: Must surrender weapons
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were included in amnesty

narrative: Clemency Order No. 1 of 2008, issued in June 2008, covered those arrested between March 29 and June 16, 2008, from the day of the general elections to the eve of the presidential run-off. Among other things, it granted indemnity to all prisoners convicted of culpable homicide and given a determinate sentence as of June 16, 2008, thus covering those who were convicted of acts such as torture and abductions, excluding murder, rape, and fraud. Most abuses committed by ZANU-PF supporters, officials and soldiers took place in the period between the general elections in March and the presidential run-off on June 17, 2008.
